answers.answer: I looked up both meds and nothing listed for diabetes side effects. Have you discussed your meds with a pharmacist to see if they may cause increased insulin production? You should also consider a lifestyle change by cutting out carbs and simple sugars while at the same time watching your diet - the types of foods consumed - to control your diabetes.

question: I am a 57 year-old black female with Congestive Heart Failure.  I have been taking Coreg for the past seven years.  I also have high blood pressure and been prescribed Lisinopril and have been taking that for quite sometime.  Another medication that I take is Amiodarone.  I am tested at least twice a year to make sure that the Amiodarone level is not too high.  Recently after having bloodwork for  that reason, I was told that I am diabetic.  I have a problem with that because my numbers are all over the place.  No matter what I do, my numbers don't seem to go to the normal level.  After recently talking with my cardiologist, I am now under the impression that taking these medications may have increased my insulin production.  Could this be the reason that my blood glucose numbers are all over the place?  I have never had an actual blood glucose test for diabetes, so could someone please get back to me.  I don't want to worry myself, especially since I do have a heart condtion, but this is beginning to worry me more than usual.  Thank you.  MsMed.
title: MsMed
